data.text: Contents
Appendix 4: Flow chart for the management of accidental exposure to BBVS needlesticks/sharps/splashes ............................................................................................ 26
Introduction
Despite careful practice and adherence to Standard Precautions, there may be occasions when health care workers (HCWs) are accidentally exposed to blood and body fluids.

The principle of following Standard (Universal) Precautions means never assuming that there is no risk. If every patient is assumed to be potentially infected with a blood-borne infection, the same precautions to prevent transmission should be used for every procedure.
Accidental exposure to blood and body fluids puts the exposed HCW at potential risk from blood borne viruses (BBVs) including Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV.

The Health and Safety (Sharp Instruments in Healthcare) Regulations came into force May 2013. All employers are required under existing health and safety law to ensure that risks from sharps injuries are adequately assessed and appropriate control measures are in place. The Sharps Regulations build on the existing law and provide specific detail on requirements  that  must  be  taken  by  healthcare  employers  and  their  contractors.  The Regulations  specifically  describe  an  employer's  obligations  which  include avoiding  the unnecessary use of sharps, use of safer sharps (incorporating protection mechanisms), preventing the recapping of needles and placing secure containers and instructions for safe disposal of medical sharps close to the work area
Staff confidentiality will be maintained in accordance with any other treatment. The employee's wishes must be respected at all times.
Scope

The policy describes how to manage needlestick, sharps and splash injuries, and states how to protect Trust employees and contractors, as far as is reasonably practicable, from the possibility of infection by blood-borne viruses (BBV) during the course of their work.
All employees, to whom this policy is relevant, should know the action to be taken in the event of an injury, caused by infected needles, sharp objects and body fluids.

The purpose of this document is to ensure all staff employed within or contracted to the Trust via Bank, Agencies or other contractual arrangements have access to management of needlestick, sharps and splash injuries.
Definitions

table_items.text: Needlestick or sharps injuries occur when a needle or other sharp instrument accidentally penetrates the skin. This is called a percutaneous injury
If the needle or sharp instrument is contaminated with blood or other body fluid, there is the potential for transmission of infection, and when this occurs in a work context, the term
occupational exposure (to blood, body fluid or blood-borne infection) is used.
When blood or other body fluid splashes into eyes, nose or mouth or onto broken skin, the exposure is said to be mucocutaneous.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive

The Chief executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality  and  safety  of  services provided  by  the  Trust.  In  this  respect  he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation  of  this  document  is  available.  He/she  will  delegate  the  full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Director of Organisational Development

The Director of Organisational Development is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to ensure that all staff are able to comply with this document. In addition he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in this document.
Divisional Clinical Directors

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial  action  implemented  as  appropriate.  In  addition,  the  Divisional  Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes  required  throughout  the  Divisions  to  ensure  that  this  document  is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Heads of Nursing and Quality
The HONQs are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Senior and Line Managers
Managers will ensure that all members of staff (to whom it may be relevant) are familiar with the policy.
Members of Staff

Members of staff are individually responsible for complying with this policy and procedure, including that of safe working practices and the correct use of safety devices, correct disposal and the location of Needlestick Action Pack and immunisation.
The member of staff must be familiar with the procedure in the event of sustaining an injury and they must follow the procedure on every occasion.
They need to ensure they follow the correct reporting protocols and seek immediate help and advice from either Occupational Health & Wellbeing or Accident and Emergency. (Appendix 4)

Staff members must ensure that they do not take a colleagues blood sample, this must be taken in Occupational Health & Wellbeing or Accident and Emergency to ensure the sample is legally validated in accordance with Trust policy.
Occupational Health and Wellbeing

They will ensure that the policy and associated procedure is communicated to all new employees, to whom it may be relevant. They will issue Needlestick Action Packs to all clinical areas and keep a record of this. In addition they must check that all procedures have been adhered to following an actual incident; this (latter) responsibility is delegated to the Accident and Emergency department out of normal business hours.

They will ensure that employee Occupational Health & Wellbeing records are maintained and record any Needlestick, sharps or splash related incident. They have a responsibility for consulting with Microbiology and others (e.g. GUM) when making an assessment on the appropriateness of post exposure prophylaxis.
Epidemiological data relating to Needlestick, sharps and splash injuries will be collated, analysed and reported at the Infection Control Committee .
Occupational Health & Wellbeing will manage any incidents which are reported to them, ensuring the employee receives appropriate advice and treatment.
Occupational Health & Wellbeing is available to provide training for staff relating to prevention & safe working practices, and how to deal with an injury.
The Head of Occupational Health & Wellbeing will ensure the policy meets the Risk Management Standards.
Accident and Emergency

They will ensure all medical and nursing staff within the Accident and Emergency Department are completely familiar with this policy and its associated procedure. They will expedite members of staff presenting with an injury through their Nurse Triage process.
All needlestick, sharps and splash injuries which occur outside Occupational Health
& Wellbeing's opening times will be managed by Triage staff within the Accident and Emergency Department.

Accident  and  Emergency  have  a  responsibility  for  following  the  procedure and supporting members of staff who present themselves to Accident and Emergency following a needlestick, sharps or splash injury, out of hours.
All staff should be fast tracked via Triage using the Code Red – (See Appendix 7 – staff Needlestick / splash injuries)

Accident and Emergency Medical Staff are responsible for prescribing a  day starter pack of Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) following a known exposure, or suspected exposure to HIV infected blood or body fluid.
Education and Training
They will provide an annual report detailing the training that has been undertaken with regards to Needlestick, sharps and splash injuries.
RIDDOR

All incidents of occupational exposure to blood borne viruses must be reported by the Health and Safety Department to the Health and Safety Executive under the Reporting of Incidents, Diseases and dangerous Occurrences Regulations 1995 (RIDDOR).
Notification of significant exposures

All significant exposures to a blood borne virus will be reported to Public Health England via their National Surveillance of Occupational Exposure to Blood Borne Viruses programme. This is not a statutory requirement.
Who is at risk?

Epidemiological data identifies two main occupational groups most at risk, these are Nurses (both qualified and non-qualified) and Doctors. However all staff who may be exposed to contaminated sharps or needlesticks are at potential risk.
Risk of exposure is influenced by several determinants: degree of risk, the unknown donor and the severity of the incident.
Degree of Risk
All health care workers are potentially at risk from infection through exposure to blood and other body fluids. There is a particular risk when undertaking Exposure Prone Procedures (EPP).
The UK is a low prevalence area for the Hepatitis B virus, with a carriage rate of 0.1-0.5%, although rates may vary between individual communities..

The degree of risk following a needlestick or sharps injury will depend on the nature of the exposure, and the status of infection in the donor. It is important to realise that these viral infections are not common in the local population.
Even if the donor is definitely infected, the risk of contracting the disease from a needlestick, sharps or splash injury is small:
Hepatitis B - Up to 30% risk of transmission Hepatitis C - 1 to 3% risk of transmission HIV - 0.3% risk of transmission Unknown/unidentifiable Source

If the source of the infected sharp object or body fluid is unknown then a risk assessment needs to be undertaken to determine the likely risk of contamination. This assessment will include the type of device, the work area, the severity of the injury and the epidemiological likelihood of blood-borne viruses being present. The risk assessment would need to be conducted by a senior staff member within the department (i.e. Ward Manager, Registrar) with advice and support from Occupational Health & Wellbeing, it should not be conducted solely by the recipient.

Some occupational exposures, after careful assessment may not be considered significant, that is, they do not have the potential for transmission, therefore post exposure prophylaxis is not recommended in these circumstances
Severity of the Incident

A significant exposure is when there is the potential for transmission of a blood borne virus. It is when the skin of the recipient is cut or penetrated by a needle or sharp object (e.g. scalpel, blade, trochar, bone fragment or tooth) which is contaminated by blood or other body fluid. The gauge of the needle, whether it is hollow-bore, the depth of the penetration and whether the recipient was wearing protective equipment (i.e. gloves) all contribute to the significance of the injury.
Prevention and Safe working Practice

Independent studies show that a combination of training, safer working practices and the use of medical devices incorporating sharps protection mechanisms can prevent more than 80 per cent of needlestick and sharps injuries.
Where available, safety devices should be used

Needles should not be re-sheathed manually. Needles and syringes should be disposed of as a complete unit, they should not be disassembled. Blunt-fill needles (filter and non-filter) should be used for drawing up medication from vials or ampoules.
Open footwear should not be worn in situations where blood might be spilt or sharp instruments are being used.
Blood spillages should be cleared up promptly.
Gloves should be worn for all procedures involving blood or body fluids, this includes venepuncture. The glove will have the effect of wiping off the excess blood before it penetrates the skin.
Face-shields or protective eyewear should be worn where there is a risk of aspirate contaminating the HCW.
Improved Sharps Disposal
Studies in the United States and Europe have shown significant reductions in the numbers of needlestick injuries from improving sharps disposal.

Portable sharps bins should be available for staff at all times, to allow the used needle or sharp to be disposed of safely at the point of use. This should also reduce the number of incidents resulting from needles being left in bedding. The sharps bins should be puncture resistant, of adequate depth and capacity and conform to British Standard 7320.
Action following a Needlestick, sharps or splash injury
First Aid (Self-Administered)
If the mouth or eyes are involved, they should be washed thoroughly with water.
If contact lenses are worn, eye irrigation should take place before and after removing the lenses.
If skin is punctured, free bleeding should be gently encouraged and the wound should be washed with soap and water, but not scrubbed or sucked.
If appropriate, the wound should then be covered with a waterproof dressing.
Reporting the Injury

The member of staff who has been injured must inform their manager or person in charge as soon as possible, a Trust Incident report (on line) should be completed in accordance with Trust incident reporting policy and procedure.
All wards and clinical areas will have a “Needlestick Action Pack”. The pack will contain all the information necessary to ensure the correct action is taken.

The  person in  charge  along  with  the  member  of  staff  (recipient)  will  complete “Recipient Needlestick Risk Assessment” form (appendix 1).This will help determine the likelihood and severity of the exposure incident.
If the injury occurs during core hours (Monday to Friday, 8.00 – 4.30) it must be reported immediately to Occupational Health & Wellbeing on extension 3591.
If the injury occurred outside of these times, the member of staff  must attend Accident and Emergency immediately and then attend Occupational Health and Wellbeing the following working day

Prompt action is absolutely crucial, especially if the risk assessment indicates that Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) is required. PEP should ideally be administered within the first hour following a significant exposure.
The member of staff will bring the completed risk assessment form with them to either Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E

The member of staff will need to have bloods taken for serum save – this can only be undertaken by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or Accident & Emergency to ensure they can be legally validated in accordance with Trust policy.
The bloods must be an identified validated sample (IVS). An IVS is defined as:
The Health Care Worker (HCW) should show proof of identity with photo ID (e.g. Trust ID badge, new driver's license or passport).
The sample should be taken by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E.
The sample should be delivered to the Laboratory in the usual manner, not transported by the HCW.

When the results are received, the clinical notes should be checked for a record that the sample was generated by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E – microbiology will only authorise samples from OH & A&E
Assessing the Risk

In assessing the risk of exposure, certain factors need to be taken into consideration: whether the source patient can be identified or not, and, if they can be identified, is their blood-borne virus status known or unknown (Appendix 1)
Source Patient Identifiable - But Status Unknown

If the source patient is identifiable, it is important to establish through their healthcare records and in consultation with the clinician responsible for their care, whether they have a blood borne virus.

If the status is unknown, then further action needs to be taken. The Senior Sister or Registrar should speak to the patient and, using the booklet “Helping Your Carer” (appendix 2 and 3), they should explain what has happened and request consent for a blood sample to be taken. A comment should be made in the patient's healthcare records “source patient in staff blood contamination incident, consent obtained to test blood”. Or “blood taken following a staff blood contamination incident”.

‘Source needlestick bloods' should be written in the clinical details section of the blood form. Source patients' blood will be tested for HIV P24 antigen and HIV antibodies, HBsAg, HbeAg, HCV antibody & HCV PCR. Several factors will be taken into consideration by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E to determine risk:
Source patient:
The risk of being infected with HIV is increased in:
People who have lived as an adult in sub-Saharan Africa
Men who have sex with men
Intravenous drug users
Children with HIV-infected mothers
People who have had unprotected sex with a partner known to have HIV or any of the above risk factors
The risk of being infected with hepatitis C is increased by:
Receipt of unscreened blood or untreated plasma products (in the UK prior to September 1991 and 1985 respectively).
Sharing of injecting equipment whilst misusing drugs.
Sharps injury or mucous membrane splash exposure to blood from patients known to be infected, or at risk of infection with hepatitis C.

Involvement as a health care worker or a patient in invasive medical, surgical, dental or midwifery procedures in parts of the world where infection control precautions may have been inadequate; or with populations with a high prevalence of hepatitis C infection (e.g. Egypt).
The risk of being infected with hepatitis B is increased in:
Intravenous drug users
Men who have sex with men
Children with hepatitis B-infected mothers
People who have had unprotected sex with a partner known to have HIV or any of the above risk factors
Recipient:
Determine the member of staffs' Hepatitis B immunity status (this can be established by Occupational Health & Wellbeing):
Unvaccinated?
One, two, three or more doses of hepatitis B vaccine?
Date of last booster?
Most recent HBsAb result and date?
Natural immunity? (HBcAb positive and HbsAg negative)
Other Factors that may increase the risk, and influence management of the incident are:
Percutaneous injury rather than mucous membrane or broken skin exposure
Injury with a device from a source patient's artery or vein
Blood exposure rather than exposure to blood-stained fluid, diluted blood (e.g. in local anaesthetic solution) or other body fluid
Injury from hollow bore rather than solid bore needle
Injury from wide gauge rather than narrow gauge needle
Deep rather than superficial injury
Visible blood on the device
No protective equipment used (e.g. gloves, double gloves, eye protection)
First-aid measures not implemented (washing, bleeding)
Having taken into consideration all of the above, Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E may decide to treat the recipient as if they had received an injury from a BBV positive source.
Source Patient Known – Status Known
If the source patient can be identified, and the blood-borne virus status of the patient is known then the following needs to be considered:
If the source patient is infected with HIV

In the case of definite exposures to blood or other high-risk body fluids known or considered to be at high risk of HIV infection, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be offered as soon as possible, preferably within one hour of the incident. The Expert Advisory Group on AIDS (EAGA) guidance states that PEP should not

be considered after  hours as there is no evidence that it works. Advice should be sought from consultant microbiologist and consultant occupational physician if consideration is being given to prescribing PEP after  hours

The decision to prescribe PEP should be taken collaboratively with Occupational Health & Wellbeing (or Accident and Emergency out of hours) and the HIV team (appendix 4). A 5 day starter pack of PEP is permanently available within the A&E department. Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E will arrange follow-up appointment with HIV team.
Refer to paragraph 5 for more details on PEP, and Pharmacy PEP Guidelines Ref: CP/GU/00069.
Take blood from recipient for serum save.
If the source patient is infected with Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

There is no prophylaxis available for hepatitis C. Blood should be taken (Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E) from the recipient and serum sent for saving and storage. Transmission is unlikely from HCV RNA negative sources.

Occupational Health & Wellbeing will arrange for bloods to be taken at 6 weeks post injury. If blood test result for Hepatitis C is positive, Occupational health will arrange for referral a referral to Hepatologist as part of fast Track policy:
HCV RNA at six weeks
HCV RNA and HCV antibodies at 12 weeks
HCV antibodies at 24 weeks after the exposure
If any of the results are positive, the baseline sample should be tested for HCV antibodies.

If the source patient is infected with Hepatitis B virus (HBV) If the staff member is not immune to hepatitis B, the patient's HBsAg status should be requested urgently. The Consultant Microbiologist should be contacted, to decide whether Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin is indicated.
When the employee attends Occupational Health & Wellbeing, they will be commenced on an accelerated course of Hepatitis B immunisation in line with the Green Book guidance.
If the staff member has received a course of Hepatitis B vaccine in the past a booster is recommended after exposure to the virus.
Follow-up blood testing will only be necessary if the staff member was non-immune at the time of the incident.
Test for HBsAg at:
Six weeks
Three months
Six months
And save serum at the time of the incident
Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin

Specific hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) provides passive immunity and can give immediate but temporary protection after accidental inoculation or contamination with hepatitis B-infected blood. HBIG is given concurrently with hepatitis B vaccine and does not affect the development of active immunity. If infection has already occurred at the time of immunisation, virus multiplication may not be inhibited completely, but severe illness and, most importantly, development of the carrier state may be prevented.

HBIG is used after exposure to give rapid protection until hepatitis B vaccine, which should be given at the same time, becomes effective. The use of HBIG in addition to vaccine is recommended only in high-risk situations or in a known non-responder to vaccine. Whenever immediate protection is required, immunisation with the vaccine should be given. When appropriate, this should be combined with simultaneous administration of HBIG at a different site. HBIG should be given as soon as possible, ideally within 48 hours, although it should still be considered up to a week after exposure.

HBIG can be administered in the upper outer quadrant of the buttock or anterolateral thigh. If more than 5ml is given to adults, the immunoglobulin should be divided into smaller amounts and administered to different sites. HBIG may be administered, at a different site, at the same time as hepatitis B vaccine.
Source Patient Unknown or Unable to Perform Test
These cases should be considered on an individual basis. As much detail about the exposure as possible should be obtained.

There will usually be no follow-up other than the initial serum save and check for HBV immunity (if required) for the staff member, unless there are particular reasons for concern (e.g. patients in the clinical area known or suspected to be infected with a blood-borne virus).
If the staff member is very anxious, Occupational Health & Wellbeing will follow-up for testing for HIV, HCV and HBV (if not immune).
Patient Refuses to Consent or is Unable to Consent

If the source patient is unconscious when the injury occurs, consent should be sought once the patient has regained consciousness. If appropriate the recipient of the injury may be prescribed post-exposure prophylaxis until consent can be obtained and results are known.

If  the  source  patient  refuses  testing,  or  is  unable  to  give  or  withhold  consent because of mental illness or disability, or they do not regain consciousness within 48 hrs, the risk assessment should consider the severity of the risk to the recipient and appropriate action taken.

Testing of the source patient should not take place without the source patient's consent, except in exceptional circumstances, for example an existing specimen of blood may be tested if there is a strong reason to believe that the patient may be positive to a BBV. A Consultant in charge of the case should give consent for this to proceed. With the Mental Capacity Act and Human Tissue Act we can only test the source if we think it is in the best interest of the source patient i.e. we think the reason they are unconscious is because of a BBV related illness. Otherwise we can't test. Management of the incident has to be based on your risk assessment. The guidance on 48hrs was before the Mental Capacity and Human Tissue Acts came into force.
Post Exposure Prophylaxis
The current standard recommended regimen for PEP is a 28-day course of a combination of anti-retroviral drugs.
Anti-retroviral drugs are not licensed for PEP, so must be prescribed on a ‘named patient' basis, by a doctor.

For  further  information  on  prescribing,  please  refer  to  the  Pharmacy  policy, “Guidelines  for  HIV  Post-exposure  Prophylaxis  (PEP)”,  Ref:  CP/GU/00069  , available on the Trust Intranet and in hard copy libraries, Q-pulse, and in the medicines information folder in A & E. Queries from the prescribing Doctor should be  directed  to  Pharmacy  Medicines  Information  (in  hours)  and  the  on-call Pharmacist (out of hours).
If A&E stocks are used, in working hours call Pharmacy dispensary and out of hours, contact the on-call Pharmacist via switchboard.

The regimen may need to be modified if there is evidence that the source patient is infected with a virus that is resistant to any of these drugs. In this case, specialist advice should be sought from the HIV physician treating the source patient.
Side Effects
Anti-retroviral drugs have side-effects including:
Nausea  Fatigue  Peripheral  Bone-marrow neuropathy  suppression
Vomiting  Headache  Renal calculi  Liver  function disturbance
Abdominal  Rashes  Diarrhoea
pain
Lethargy Pancreatitis Glucose
intolerance

Exposed staff members should be counselled about the side-effects, and the potential risks and benefits of PEP should be considered very carefully, so that staff can make an informed choice whether to take PEP or not.

In view of the recommendation to start PEP as soon as possible, starter-packs containing enough drugs for 5 days (to cover weekends and public holidays) should be made available to avoid delay due to dispensing a prescription. These are held in the Controlled Drug cupboard in Accident and Emergency. The drugs are expensive and starter-packs must be checked regularly to ensure expiry dates are not exceeded.
Occupational Health & Wellbeing do not prescribe PEP, any staff requiring PEP will be sent to Accident and Emergency with the referral form (see Appendix 8) for the starter pack.
The staff member will be referred to HIV team for an urgent appointment who will then follow up weekly whilst the staff member is taking PEP.
The staff member should return for testing (with informed consent) for HIV P24 antigen and HIV antibodies, at, three months and six months after completing post- exposure prophylaxis.
If the staff member tests positive for HIV P24 antigen and HIV antibodies, it will be necessary to test the stored baseline sample and refer them to a specialist in HIV medicine.
The employee should be advised on safe sex (barrier contraception) and avoiding blood donation for 6 months following BBV exposure incident (confirmed positive).
Training requirements
All newly appointed Trust staff (including Junior Doctors) will receive training at induction, to include:
The risks associated with blood and body-fluid exposures
The correct use and disposal of sharps
The use of medical devices incorporating sharps protection mechanisms
The action required following exposure

In  addition,  Managers  should  ensure  at  local  induction  that  training  and familiarisation with the Needlestick Action Pack, is given. Including making staff aware of this policy and procedure, as well as making sure they are aware of:
The risks associated with blood and body-fluid exposures
The correct use and disposal of sharps
The use of medical devices incorporating sharps protection mechanisms
Bespoke training will be provided where trend analysis has identified a training issue.
Periodical events will take place to raise awareness of the risks from needlesticks and sharps injuries to all Trust staff.
Training will be provided to clinical staff attending Foundation IV training programme and the IV Refresher programme.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR Working Policy Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 8)

Helping your Carer

data.text: Information Sheet and Consent Form for Source Patient
Introduction

There is a degree of anxiety for doctors and nurses when blood or other body fluids contaminate them at work. Very rarely blood contains viruses which can be contagious if they come into contact with damaged skin. As health staff may work for many years in close contact with patients the risk of being contaminated with blood is ever present. The fear of catching a blood borne virus is therefore very real.
The help we need

When a member of staff is contaminated with blood they themselves may require treatment. In deciding which treatment is best we need your help in checking your blood for three important viruses – hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV. You have not been singled out; it is Trust policy to approach all patients in this situation.

The chances of any of these viruses being present in your blood are extremely small. However should this be the case, you will be told by your doctor and all the necessary arrangements for further care will be made.

Please feel free to ask any further questions of the doctor or trained nurse who has asked you for this consent. Your consent is entirely voluntary, but if given, it will help us to reassure and treat the member of staff involved in his incident.

People often worry that if they have an HIV P24 antigen and HIV antibodies test that this will affect any later request for life insurance etc. The position of the Assoc. of British Insurers is that insurance companies should not ask whether you have had an HIV P24 antigen and HIV antibodies test. They should ask only if you have had a positive HIV test or are receiving treatment for HIV/AIDS. Therefore a negative test taken purely because someone has been exposed to your blood should have no impact on a future request for insurance.
